status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector states that National Grid is installing a new gas main on Dorchester Ave. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. The Inspector talked to the crew and reviewed the proper posting procedures. Going forward there should be no issues with the postings. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

description: I am writing this letter to state that I believe Billy Baker, the president of SBYS has to much control and power over the league. I have had problems with him in the past refusing to let children sign up for the league. I am not the only one that disagrees with his actions and behavior. I am petitioning to have him removed from the league. Last year there were numerous families turned away. He states too many kids. Excuse me? How do you turn active participents away? This is unacceptable. My sons team last year had 17 children the night of the soccer parade. By week 3 there were 10 children. Every practice there were the same dedicated 4 children that showed up. He should not be able to turn away our children. This is a community league. With the drug epidemic on our hands we should be teaching our children how to be engaged in the community and participate in sports and stay busy now then trying to fix a problem we could have aimed to prevent. I honestly appreciate you reading my email. I hope if anyone of our community leaders are free this evening they can pop down Moakely Field to the parade. It begins at 4:30. Please help me be the voice for our children. Hope to see you all this evening. Thank you.
address: Intersection Of Msgr Dennis F. O'callaghan Way & Old Colony Ave, South Boston

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  called the contractor working for National Grid and requested that the pavement markings be restored ASAP. Because of the cold weather the markings may be returned with paint instead of the thermal plastic, which needs warmer weather. They will need to come back in the Spring and return the thermal plastic. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to National Grid. Since the Public Works has a moratorium on all concrete and brick work beginning in late November, this sidewalk may not be returned to brick until the Spring. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. If at anytime the asphalt patch becomes unacceptable National Grid will be required to make repairs.  This includes the Winter period if need be. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Thank you for your concern. While school may have not been in session, the 24hr count was in fact performed under real-life circumstances and in accordance with BTD and US-standard traffic study procedures. School in session would increase volumes during the morning and afternoon, but it would not change the speeds on the street. The distribution would remain the same or very close to the same. On any street, a number of factors guide how fast people naturally travel, including roadway width, geometry, and sight lines. This is not impacted by the volume of vehicles using the street. Your original request was for speed limit signs. BTD performs dozens of speed studies on residential streets each year and not one of them in our memory has shown an average speed of higher than 30mph, the statutory limit. We do understand that speeds lower than that are preferable and safer, however the speed limit is controlled by the State. As such, BTD is unable to install speed limit signs without state approval. We still believe, however, that installing one on this street would be counterproductive and increase speeds. No matter what actions are taken, there will always be a few outliers that speed, which is why this case was forwarded to Boston Police for speed enforcement. It has been noted that the double yellow centerline has faded on this street and a maintenance request was already forwarded to operations to have it restriped. We have found that the presence of a center line narrows the lane and lowers speeds.
description: This speed study was done when school was out and half of Boston is away. Needs to be repeated under actual real-life circumstances.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Sorry for the delay in responding to your concerns from earlier this month.  I received the complaint recently.   The project entailed cleaning and lining our sewer interceptor.   The work is continuous once the liner is installed.  We perform the work overnight because of the reduced sewer flow.   We apologize for the inconvenience the project presents.  The lining process allows for the work to be completed in a few days, whereas if the interceptor had to be replaced it would have taken a few months.   We appreciate your patience as we are completing this complex project in South Boston. Should you have any further questions regarding the project, our website BWSC.org provides an overview of the project ?Reserved Channel Sewer Separation Project?   You can contact me directly as well if you have any further concerns.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to National Grid. Sidewalks are usually required to be restored within 60 days. Since the Public Works has a moratorium on all concrete and brick  work that began in late November, this sidewalk will not be returned to brick until the Spring. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. If at anytime the asphalt patch becomes unacceptable National Grid will be required to make repairs. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

description:
Mr Mayor,
American Revolution
1776
British evacuate Boston On this day in 1776, British forces are forced to evacuate Boston following General George Washington’s successful placement of fortifications and cannons on Dorchester Heights, which overlooks the city from the south.

During the evening of March 4, American Brigadier General John Thomas, under orders from Washington, secretly led a force of 800 soldiers and 1,200 workers to Dorchester Heights and began fortifying the area. To cover the sound of the construction, American cannons, besieging Boston from another location, began a noisy bombardment of the outskirts of the city. By the morning, more than a dozen cannons from Fort Ticonderoga had been brought within the Dorchester Heights fortifications. British General Sir William Howe hoped to use the British ships in Boston Harbor to destroy the American position, but a storm set in, giving the Americans ample time to complete the fortifications and set up their artillery. Realizing their position was now indefensible, 11,000 British troops and some 1,000 Loyalists departed Boston by ship on March 17, sailing to the safety of Halifax, Nova Scotia.

The bloodless liberation of Boston by the Patriots brought an end to a hated eight-year British occupation of the city, known for such infamous events as the “Boston Massacre,” in which five colonists were shot and killed by British soldiers. The British fleet had first entered Boston Harbor on October 2, 1768, carrying 1,000 soldiers. Having soldiers living among them in tents on Boston Common–a standing army in 18th-century parlance–infuriated Bostonians.
address: Intersection Of National St & Thomas Park, South Boston

6:30 AM Trash pick up at Hale House in residential neighborhood blatantly violates posted no commercial traffic between 11 PM and 7 AM law.  This clanging garbage truck wakes everyone sleeping along this alleyway from Berkeley to Clarendon and sustains its disturbance as they drag out a large metal wheeled dumpster and yell over that noise to communicate. status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Please see the original case closure note below. Work will not take place until the Spring time because of the weather. The CIU has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to Keash Excavation.. Utility companies and private contractors are required to restore the sidewalk to original condition within 60 days of completion of their temporary work. Because we are in the winter moratorium season of concrete/brick work (November 15-April 15), the restoration work will be held off until next spring. The utility company has been notified that the repairs must take place next April. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. The CIU will remind the utility companies next April about their obligation to restore the sidewalks within 2 weeks of the 2014 construction season. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office. 617-438-8517 Cell.
